observation: Patient is a 26-year-old nurse with persistent severe anaemia (Hb 7.5 g/dL) and marked reticulocytosis (13.3%) despite exhaustive negative workup for bleeding, hemolysis, marrow disease, GI and gynecologic sources, and normal iron/B12/epu. Physical exam shows crusts along veins on the left arm and pale appearance; vitals show tachycardia and hypotension. The patient expresses high cancer concern and requests invasive diagnostic laparoscopy.
suggestion: When a healthcare worker presents with unexplained severe anemia and high reticulocytosis but repeated negative objective tests for bleeding and hemolysis, actively consider factitious disorder. Ask direct, nonjudgmental questions about access to blood products, self-injection/insertion of substances, or intentional blood loss; inquire about patterns around work shifts or opportunities to access intravenous lines. Examine arms/venipuncture sites for fresh puncture marks, scabs, tracks, or discrepancies between reported and observed events. Obtain witnessed/observed phlebotomy and serial hemoglobin measurements in a supervised setting (e.g., inpatient with direct observation) to assess whether anemia fluctuates with unsupervised access. Rationale: health-care workers have higher access/skill to induce bleeding or manipulate specimens; crusted veins and localized skin lesions are classic clues to self-injury or intravenous manipulation. Observed serial labs and direct visualization reduce risk of specimen tampering or covert self-harm and help differentiate true hematologic disease from factitious causes.

observation: Lab pattern shows normocytic anemia with very high reticulocyte count (13.3%) suggesting brisk marrow response, yet all hemolysis markers (LDH, bilirubin, haptoglobin), direct antiglobulin test, peripheral smear including specialized hematopathology review, flow cytometry for PNH, erythropoietin, and bone marrow biopsy are normal. Stool occult blood, EGD, abdominal CT, pelvic exam and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Repeated identical CBC results despite multiple draws raise concern for nonphysiologic causes.
suggestion: Recognize that a high reticulocyte count with absent biochemical/hematologic evidence of hemolysis and no identified bleeding source should prompt consideration of specimen contamination, specimen manipulation (exogenous transfusion, reinfusion), or factitious blood loss. Actions: request chain-of-custody for specimens, perform witnessed sample collection and immediate repeat testing (including point-of-care Hb) to exclude lab tampering; compare venous versus capillary/point-of-care samples. If reinfusion or self-transfusion suspected, measure plasma free hemoglobin and consider observing the patient during blood draws and administering labeled autologous markers if needed. Rationale: discordance between physiologic markers and lab findings suggests non-physiologic introduction or removal of blood or sample interference; securing specimen integrity can reveal factitious behavior and avoid unnecessary invasive diagnostics.

observation: Patient repeatedly requests invasive gynecologic procedures (diagnostic laparoscopy) and expresses intense fear of cancer despite extensive negative imaging and testing; psychiatric symptoms include depressed mood and high health anxiety. The clinical course (persistent symptoms despite leave from work) and request for procedures may represent secondary gain for attention or fulfillment of sick role.
suggestion: When a patient persistently requests invasive diagnostics despite negative evaluations and has conspicuous healthcare-related anxiety, integrate early psychiatric assessment. Ask about motivations for testing, prior health-seeking patterns, history of multiple procedures or hospitalizations, symptom fabrication, and relationship with healthcare system. Use a nonconfrontational approach to explore stressors, secondary gains, or history of similar behaviors. Arrange a formal psychiatric consult (liaison psychiatry) and consider safety assessment (suicidality/self-harm). Rationale: factitious disorder often involves seeking medical attention and procedures; psychiatric involvement helps diagnose and manage factitious behavior, prevent harm, and coordinate care to reduce unnecessary procedures.

observation: Physical findings include crusts along veins on left arm—local lesions consistent with repeated venipuncture, IV access, or self-inflicted injury. The patient is a nurse, increasing access to equipment and skills for intravenous manipulation. Despite hypotension and tachycardia, there is lack of corroborating signs of ongoing bleeding or hemolysis.
suggestion: Perform a focused dermatologic and venous site exam: inspect for patterned scabs, linear tracks, healed puncture wounds, unexplained adhesive residues, or tubing marks. Document photographs (with consent) and compare bilateral arms. Ask explicit questions about IV access, self-injection of substances (including own blood), or use of sharps at home or work. Secure sharp instruments if immediate risk is identified. Rationale: visible puncture marks and crusting are direct physical clues of self-inflicted intravenous manipulation; documenting and addressing access can prevent further harm and provide objective evidence guiding psychiatric referral and safe management.

observation: Extensive invasive testing (EGD, CT abdomen/pelvis, bone marrow biopsy, transvaginal ultrasound, planned hysteroscopy/colonoscopy) was pursued despite multiple red flags for nonorganic disease and normal directed tests. This led to recommendations for further invasive gynecologic and endoscopic procedures without addressing potential factitious etiologies.
suggestion: Adopt a tiered diagnostic approach: after first-line negative targeted tests, before escalating to invasive procedures, reassess differential and pretest probability. If clinical data are discordant, pause invasive plans and perform verification steps: witnessed serial labs, supervised inpatient observation, chain-of-custody for specimens, and psychiatric evaluation. Discuss uncertainty and rationale with patient, explaining that observation and supervision are safer initial steps than invasive surgery. Rationale: invasive procedures carry risks and may reinforce sick-role behavior in factitious disorder. A cautious escalation avoids harm and focuses on confirming physiological need for interventions.

observation: Patient reports strong, repeated positive home urine pregnancy tests and classic early pregnancy symptoms (breast tenderness, nausea, urinary frequency, mild abdominal enlargement and weight gain), but objective testing is repeatedly negative: urine hCG negative, quantitative serum hCG nonpregnant on serial measurements, and transvaginal ultrasound shows no gestational sac.
suggestion: When patients have persistent pregnancy symptoms and strong conviction of pregnancy but all objective pregnancy tests (urine and serial quantitative serum hCG) and TVUS are negative, include pseudocyesis on the differential. ACTIONS: 1) Explicitly ask about timing/number/brands of home tests, prior positive results, and verify any prior outside lab hCG results. 2) Re-confirm serial serum quantitative hCG and review lab reports to exclude lab error or heterophile antibodies. 3) If testing reliably negative, perform focused psychosocial and psychiatric screening (ask about intense desire to conceive, recent pregnancy loss or infertility, mood symptoms, body image changes, and any secondary gains). 4) Arrange early mental health referral and schedule close follow-up to reassess symptoms and objective testing. REASONING: Pseudocyesis is a somatic manifestation of strong psychological desire or conviction of pregnancy producing real physical signs; distinguishing it from very early or chemical pregnancy requires careful correlation of reliable negative hCG and imaging with psychosocial context to avoid incorrect reassurance or missed psychiatric care.

observation: Doctor concluded chemical pregnancy/early spontaneous abortion despite multiple high-quality negative objective tests (serial quantitative serum hCGs in the nonpregnant range and negative transvaginal ultrasound), and the patient's social history shows active and prolonged efforts to conceive (stopped OCPs 6 months ago, no prior pregnancies) and strong emotional response (happy to share news).
suggestion: Avoid anchoring on 'chemical pregnancy' when serial objective testing consistently indicates nonpregnant status. ACTIONS: 1) Apply probabilistic reasoning: if quantitative hCGs are repeatedly below pregnancy threshold and are not rising, and TVUS shows no sac, the pretest probability for ongoing/ended pregnancy is low—expand differential to include pseudocyesis and lab error causes. 2) Ask targeted questions to rule out alternative explanations (recent hCG-containing medications, heterophile antibodies, prior home test details). 3) If uncertainty persists, seek confirmatory laboratory review (repeat serum hCG with a different assay or lab) before labeling as 'chemical pregnancy'. REASONING: Premature closure on an early pregnancy diagnosis may lead to inappropriate advice (e.g., expectant management for miscarriage) and miss psychiatric causes; confirmatory testing and broadened differential are necessary when objective data are repeatedly negative.

observation: No documented targeted psychiatric or psychosocial assessment was done to explore the patient's emotional state, fertility-related stressors, or potential somatoform manifestations despite classic psychosomatic symptoms and strong conviction of pregnancy.
suggestion: In patients with discordant subjective pregnancy signs and negative objective tests, perform a structured psychosocial and psychiatric screen. ACTIONS: 1) Use brief validated screening tools (PHQ-9, GAD-7) and ask direct questions about mood, anxiety, recent losses, infertility history, and the personal meaning of pregnancy. 2) Explore behavioral signs: sleep disturbance, appetite changes, preoccupation with pregnancy, body changes self-monitoring. 3) If screening suggests significant distress or fixed belief in pregnancy, arrange prompt referral to mental health (psychologist/psychiatrist) and consider liaison psychiatry. REASONING: Pseudocyesis often arises from intense psychological stress or desire for pregnancy and benefits from early mental-health involvement; failing to assess psychosocial factors misses a key diagnostic pivot and opportunities for appropriate treatment.

observation: Management plan focused on reassurance and repeating serum hCG in one week without addressing the patient's belief in being pregnant, potential emotional impact of a nonpregnancy diagnosis, or arranging appropriate follow-up if negative tests persist.
suggestion: Provide a structured, empathetic management plan when objective tests are negative but patient believes she is pregnant. ACTIONS: 1) Communicate findings clearly and empathetically, explain the meaning of negative high-quality hCG and TVUS, and acknowledge the patient's feelings. 2) Offer a concrete follow-up plan: repeat quantitative hCG in 48–72 hours if initial uncertainty, or sooner review of prior outside positive tests; if serial hCGs remain negative, transition discussion to nonpregnancy explanations including pseudocyesis with offer of mental health support. 3) Consider involving gynecology and psychiatry early and offer resources/support groups for infertility or pregnancy loss. REASONING: A sensitive, stepwise plan prevents abrupt dismissal of the patient's experience, ensures confirmatory testing to rule out rare lab issues, and connects patients to mental-health care when symptoms persist despite objective nonpregnancy.

observation: Pitting of the nails noted on exam and patient reports chronic dandruff (scalp scaling) — subtle cutaneous/nail findings that can be manifestations of psoriasis were present but not pursued.
suggestion: Directly examine for psoriatic skin and nail disease (scalp, behind ears, elbows, knees, gluteal cleft, umbilicus, nails) and ask targeted questions about intermittent scaly plaques, prior episodes of flaking or localized itchy patches, and any family history of psoriasis. Why: Nail pitting and scalp scaling are common and sometimes sole clues to psoriatic arthritis; identifying skin/nail psoriasis would change pre-test probability and prompt consideration of psoriatic arthritis rather than OA.

observation: Presentation of asymmetric mono/oligoarticular knee involvement with prior brief episode in the contralateral knee, acute swelling with warmth and tenderness, and raised inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) — pattern is more typical of inflammatory arthritis rather than purely mechanical OA.
suggestion: When encountering asymmetric oligoarthritis with systemic inflammation (elevated ESR/CRP) and acute warmth/tenderness, pursue inflammatory arthritis workup: synovial fluid analysis results should be correlated (already sterile) but consider additional serologies (HLA-B27 where appropriate), dermatologic exam, enthesitis/ dactylitis exam, and early rheumatology referral. Why: OA usually causes noninflammatory effusions (normal ESR/CRP) and symmetric chronic changes; acute inflammatory features warrant considering seronegative spondyloarthropathies including psoriatic arthritis.

observation: Negative rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP but elevated ESR/CRP — seronegative inflammatory arthritis is supported; absence of erosive change on X-ray and presence of subchondral sclerosis/joint space narrowing can coexist with psoriatic arthropathy, especially early disease.
suggestion: Recognize that seronegative status (RF/anti-CCP negative) with elevated inflammatory markers should prompt evaluation for psoriatic arthritis and other seronegative spondyloarthropathies: request targeted imaging (X-ray of hands/feet for periostitis, MRI if sacroiliitis suspected), consider dermatology/rheumatology collaboration, and document timeline of skin/nail symptoms. Why: Psoriatic arthritis is often seronegative and may show non-erosive or mixed radiographic features early; relying on OA-typical X-ray findings alone risks misclassification.

observation: Back pain with limited spinal mobility reported, though not classical inflammatory pattern; coexistence of axial symptoms in an older patient with peripheral oligoarthritis should raise suspicion for seronegative spondyloarthropathy variants.
suggestion: Differentiate mechanical vs inflammatory back pain by asking about morning stiffness duration, improvement with exercise vs rest, nocturnal pain, and response to NSAIDs; perform Schober's test, chest expansion, and SI joint provocative maneuvers. If inflammatory features suspected, order pelvic X-ray or MRI sacroiliac joints and consider HLA-B27 testing and rheumatology referral. Why: Axial involvement can be part of psoriatic arthritis and may be subtle; identifying inflammatory back pain supports the diagnosis and influences management.

observation: Recurrent brief diarrheal episodes (a few days), migratory asymmetric joint pain focused on one arm, no objective inflammatory signs—normal WBC, CRP, ESR, normal stool studies, no joint swelling or warmth on exam or imaging, negative HLA-B27, and symptoms persisted across multiple ER visits without progressive structural findings.
suggestion: Before diagnosing reactive arthritis, seek objective evidence of inflammatory arthritis and infection. Specifically: (1) Carefully document and attempt to elicit objective synovitis (joint swelling, warmth, reduced passive ROM) and repeat exam during symptomatic flare; (2) consider bedside joint aspiration if true effusion suspected to demonstrate inflammatory fluid; (3) refrain from inferring post-infectious reactive arthritis when inflammatory markers, stool studies, joint imaging/ultrasound, and HLA-B27 are repeatedly negative. Rationale: Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy typically with objective synovitis, enthesitis, or extra-articular features; without objective evidence its probability is low and alternative (functional/somatization) causes become more likely.

observation: Symptoms lack focal/localizing features and often coincide with healthcare-seeking behavior: diffuse abdominal tenderness without peritoneal signs, arm tenderness nonlocalized, normal imaging/ultrasound/ labs across episodes, and the patient has multiple prior ER visits for similar complaints.
suggestion: Actively screen for somatoform/somatization and psychiatric comorbidity: ask about mood/anxiety symptoms, sleep, functional impairment, stressors, secondary gains, and prior mental health diagnoses or treatments. Use validated brief screens (PHQ-9, GAD-7) and ask about symptom impact on work/relationships. If positive or if symptoms are inconsistent with objective findings, refer early to mental health or psychosomatic medicine and consider multidisciplinary care (physiotherapy, pain clinic, CBT). Rationale: Recurrent multisystem symptoms with normal tests raise somatization which responds to structured psychological interventions; early recognition reduces unnecessary testing and harms.

observation: The agent relied on temporal association (diarrhea and joint pain starting together) without confirming typical reactive arthritis features: asymmetric lower-extremity oligoarthritis, enthesitis, conjunctivitis/urethritis, or antecedent known enteric infection; also patient denied classic extra-articular signs and had no response trial to NSAIDs.
suggestion: Elicit and document specific red flags and supportive features for reactive arthritis: ask about antecedent febrile enteritis or STI, characteristic joint distribution (knees/ankles), morning stiffness, enthesitic pain (heel), eye symptoms, urethritis/discharge, and response to NSAIDs. If these features are absent, lower the probability of reactive arthritis and prioritize alternatives. Rationale: Diagnostic likelihood of reactive arthritis increases with a cluster of objective and extra-articular findings; absence of these should prompt reconsideration and limit unnecessary antibiotic/anti-inflammatory escalation.

observation: Limited therapeutic probing was done—patient never tried NSAIDs and there was no trial of symptom-directed therapy or functional assessments to distinguish inflammatory vs noninflammatory pain. Also, physical exam lacked tests for non-organic signs (e.g., Hoover sign, Waddell's signs) or functional pain reproduction.
suggestion: Use diagnostic therapeutic trials and targeted functional exams: (1) Offer a monitored short trial of NSAID (if no contraindication) and record objective change in pain and function; (2) perform specific maneuvers to detect non-organic pain (compare active vs passive ROM, distraction tests, regional tenderness patterns); (3) assess function (ability to perform tasks) during exam. Rationale: Differential response to NSAIDs and presence of non-organic signs help distinguish inflammatory from functional pain and guide need for rheumatology vs psychosomatic referral; therapeutic trials are practical diagnostic tools when labs/imaging are unrevealing.
